The business is going well and they have become well known to their customers. With this new loan, they will purchase supplies such as fibers, ropes, nails for their business.

Leila has put a lot of effort into this business and feels good that they've been able to grow. Later on, they would like to set up their business in a better location in order to offer their customers the best service and attention. She appreciates the support they have received to help achieve their goals and dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase supplies for her broom business.

loans.name: Rodrigo A

texts.en:
Rodrigo A. M. is from the village of Mayor's Village, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 56 years old. Rodrigo is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Rodrigo owns & operates a tricycle transport service. Rodrigo has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 7500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Rodrigo joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rodrigo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from GDMPC. Rodrigo is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Rodrigo from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair an existing vehicle

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita G. is from the village of Centro Napo, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old. Lolita is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Lolita owns & operates a "sari-sari" or general store, selling daily used products such as soap, shampoo, toothpaste etc., in the local community. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lolita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Lolita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Aneth

texts.en:
Aneth is a member of the Ikuti borrower group in Nzonwe, Mbeya, she is 45 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 18 and 16  years  old.

Aneth has owned a clothing business selling clothes for 10 years, she works 8 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Aneth`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the the amount of 200,000 Tsh  in order to buy more clothes fro sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Aneth hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more  clothes

loans.name: Makunguru Group

texts.en:
Maura is a member of the Makunguru borrower group in  Mwanjelwa, Mbeya. She is 50  year old woman, she is married and a  mother of  7 children.

Maura has owned a shop business selling rice, cooking oil , sugar for 6 years. She works 7 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately  60,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Maura`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more shop commodities for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Maura hopes to save more money and expand her business.

Yovita and Faines are another member of the same borrower group, they also requested the loan amount of 200,000 each one  Tsh in order to expand  their  business.

loans.use: To buy more  commodities for shop business

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a member of the Maendeleo borrower group in Nzonwe, Mbeya. She is 45 year old woman, she is married and a  mother of  3 children. Her children are 18, 16 and  5  years old.

Joyce has owned a food business selling tomatoes potatoes etc for 2 years, she works 10 hours a day and she  earns  a monthly profit  approximately 360,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This s Joyce`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 100,000  Tsh in order to buy more food commodities for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Joyce hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more potatoes, tomatoes, anion

loans.name: Florencia

texts.en:
Like most enterprising housewives in the Philippines, Florencia S., 47 years old, makes a living from buying and selling cosmetic items and apparel from prominent direct-selling companies (Avon, Sundance, Natasha, Marikina Shoe Exchange, etc.), which has been a tried and tested source of income for them.

Florencia’s family lives in Pasay City, a bustling community in the middle of the metropolis.  Her husband Renato, 48, drives his own motorized tricycle, an alternative source of income for their family.  Three of their six children are now working.  

Florencia has just started with her direct selling business only last year but she is already earning at least P11,000.00 net income per month.  She is working hard to help her husband augment their basic daily needs.  Florencia needs a new loan in the amount of P15,000.00 so she can purchase goods in advance to get more rebates from suppliers.  She dreams of seeing all their children who are still in school finish their college studies.   



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester is a member of the Lupeta borrower group in Nzonwa, Mbeya. She is 40 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 4 children. Her children are 16, 14, 10,  and 6 years old. She also cares for other 3 dependents.

Ester has owned a cafe business selling food for 2  years, she works 6  hours a day and she  earns a monthly profit approximately 100,000  Tanzanian shillings.

This is Ester`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more food commodities to her cafe business.

With the additional profit she  gains from the use of this loan, Ester hopes to save money, pay school fees and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities to her cafe business

texts.en:

Roda has owned a charcoal business for 22 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Roda`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 100,000 Tsh in order to buy more charcoal for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Roda hopes to pay school fees, get more food for family and expand her business.

loans.name: Kyelema Eyeta Nambuya Jessica Group

texts.en: N. Jessica is 30 years old, and married with two children. Since 2005 she has been running a grocery shop where she sells groundnuts, beans, maize, etc. Jessica will use her loan to purchase grocery items such as groundnuts, beans, maize, etc. for sale to her customers. She wants to increase her stock of these items so that she can save on transport costs. Jessica is an active businesswoman whose dream is to educate her children and purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items such as groundnuts, beans, maize, etc. to sell

loans.name: Ma. Dely

texts.en:
Ma. Dely A. is 40 years old and lives in Bagong Silang, Caloocan City, with her husband Sonny, 44, who works as a company driver. They have three children, two of whom are attending school. Ma. Dely has been in business for the last year buying and selling basic household necessities. She is now concentrating on food items ranging from frozen processed meats, fresh meats, and eggs, to dried fish. She sells her items in a leased space and earns 13,000 PHP net income per month.

Ma. Dely joined Kiva partner, Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative (CCT), in 2006 and has been enjoying the warm ambience of the weekly gathering of her fellowship group. Now on her ninth loan cycle with CCT, she has applied for a 22,000 PHP loan, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. She hopes to have her own stall in the marketplace soon.

About CCT
The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.
CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

Ester has owned a shop business selling rice, cooking oil, sugar for 3 years, she works 10 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings.

texts.en: M. Petronia is thirty years old, the Cashier of her group. She is a married business lady blessed with three children all going to school and she looks after six dependents of whom four are schooling. M. Petronia deals with a retail shop business for thirteen years so far. She is requesting for the loan to purchase retail items such as salt, paraffin, match boxes, sugar, soap, etc selling mostly essentials. She is an active business woman who keeps on mobilizing women in her community for developmental ideas and her dream is to educate her children as in setting a better future for them.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as salt, paraffin, match boxes, sugar, soap, etc selling mostly essentials.

texts.en:

Beina has owned a food business selling soup for 4 years, she works 10 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings.

loans.use: To purchase shop commodities in bulk for hrebusiness

loans.name: Nyoka

texts.en:
Nyoka C. is 28 years old and the mother of three children who all go to school. She is married to a peasant. Nyoka has a business at her home selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to build a charcoal store so that she can hold a better stock. In the future, Nyoka wants to employ some workers in the charcoal burning industry in the Walangwalang forest, and also hopes to buy two motorbikes for carrying bags of charcoal to the main store.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To build a charcoal store

loans.name: Suyunbubu's Group

texts.en:
Suyunbubu, the leader of this group, is 51 years old. She has raised four children, two sons and two daughters. All her children have already started adult life and earn their own livelihoods. Her eldest son works in Russia doing odd jobs at a construction site. Her eldest daughter works as a seamstress in Alamedin market in the capital. Her second son is an excavator, and her youngest daughter is a college student at the Humanities University in the capital.

Suyunbubu prefers to be independent from her children and earns her living by manufacturing curtains and tailoring. This business, which she has been working at for 20 years, makes her a humble income of $120 USD a month. Suyunbubu has also taught her daughters how to sew. With their help, Suyunbubu manages to get her work done faster. She has her own sewing machine and does all her work at home. However, she is in need of a new sewing machine as her current one has become old and inconvenient. She also needs to purchase some accessories for the sewing machine. Therefore Suyunbubu is requesting a loan to help her make these purchases and thus save valuable time. In the future, Suyunbubu hopes to marry her sons and daughters, and help her youngest daughter complete her college education.

Suyunbubu’s partners are Shailoobai, Akmoor and Akmolmol. Shailoobai, 30, is married and has a cute five-month-old daughter. He provides for his family by raising livestock. He needs a loan to buy one sheep and three goats.

Akmoor, 33, is a mother of three children. She raises livestock and sells some of her cattle at market when needed. Akmoor needs a loan to buy five or six goats for breeding.

For the last ten years, Akmolmol, 36, has been providing for her four children by raising cattle and selling milk. As the children grow, she needs to increase her income to meet their growing needs. She hopes to get a loan and buy a calf.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and to view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team, Supporters of Kyrgyzstan, at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine and supplies

loans.name: Nargiza's Group

texts.en:
The leader of this group is Nargiza, a 30-year-old woman with a strong character. She is divorced and has raised two children on her own, both of whom are at school. Even though her family consists of just three members, Nargiza has to work hard to provide them with a worthy life. She makes a living by selling video and audio CDs, DVDs and mp3 players. Sometimes, she even manages to trade in cattle. She is very fortunate to have a caring brother, who is always by her side at difficult times. When Nargiza leaves her stall to transport goods, he replaces her so that trade is not interrupted.

Two years in business have brought her evident results: purchase of a car for transporting goods, and some convenience goods for her home. Her original investment was $70 USD, and her current monthly income is around $480 USD. Nargiza's plan is to build a house and set her children on their feet by providing them with a good education. For this, Nargiza needs a loan to purchase video and audio CDs, DVDs, children’s school uniform, table napkins and diapers, as she has noticed a growing demand for these goods.

Nargiza’s partners are Nariste, Baktygul, Larisa and Nurlan. Nariste, 26, is married. Her husband is a security guard at a casino, whereas she buys milk products wholesale and sells them at the market. She needs a loan to buy butter, cottage cheese and sour cream.

Baktygul, 34, has two children. She sells foodstuffs in a small shop. In addition, she sells chewing gum, cigarettes and vitamins, at the city market. Baktygul needs a loan to purchase school equipment, cereals, soft drinks and ice-creams.

Larisa, 34, is married and has three children. She trades in fish, and her husband is a minibus driver. Larisa needs a loan to purchase frozen fish, school equipment and clothes for her children.

Nurlan, 30, is married with one child. He works as a security guard at two locations. In addition, he manages to keep cattle. He needs a loan to buy a calf.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and to view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team, Supporters of Kyrgyzstan, at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase video and audio CDs, DVDs, school uniform, napkins and diapers to sell

loans.name: Raikul's Group

texts.en: The heroine of this story is a great example of having firm goals and steadfastness to achieve them, neglecting all the ups and downs on the way. The leader of the group, Raikul is forty six years old. An unsuccessful marriage and subsequent divorce did not shake her belief in life and happiness. She has raised her children on her own and her two sons have grown up and become mature. They received all her love and have absorbed all her efforts to inspire in them family values. Now the eldest son always helps his mother. He works in a brick factory. The little son, 18, has gone to serve in the army. As to Raikul, she is engaged in animal husbandry and cattle breeding. Some years ago she bought a calf from her sister and that is how she got involved in this business. She quickly grasped the aspects of this occupation and her earnings have allowed her to pay for her eye treatment and buy better food for home. She has lots of plans about making repairs to her house and building a convenient shed, but before that, she wants to get a loan to buy a milk cow. Selling milk would bring in more money for the family budget. Raikul has three partners: Kyialbek, Nurgulya and Jumakan: Kyialbek, 33, raises livestock. Kolkhoz gave him a cow instead of a salary and Kyialbek managed to increase the total population and improve his living standards. He hopes to obtain a loan to buy a calf. Nurgulya, 24, is a housewife with two children. Besides that, she keeps some cattle and sells milk. The earnings from what she does have tremendously helped her husband buy a house. Nurgulya feels inspired to buy one more cow to increase her income. However, she needs a loan to do that. Jumakan, 49, is the mother of four children. Together with her husband they raise cattle and thus provide for themselves, as their children are grown-ups and live separately. Jumakan wants to buy a cow. This loan would enable her to make this purchase. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy a milk cow

texts.en:

Wilberforce is a married man blessed with three children and expects to provide the best for them. He also owns a banana plantation where he produces more than ten bananas daily for sale as a side income. His future plan is to increase his business and remain self-employed.

texts.en:
Mr. B. Jackson is a forty-two-year-old man who owns a retail shop at the central market. He has two kids and they are both in school.

Mr. B. Jackson has a retail shop selling mostly essential products. He is using the loan for expansion of his business: that is, purchasing sugar, flour, soap, rice, cooking oil, paraffin, and other items for sale.

Mr. B. Jackson is very happy and he hopes to work hard and even open up other shops to generate more income to cater for his family.

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Jessie D., a 27-year-old businessman from Pangarap Village, Caloocan City, has been managing his own general store in front of his house for the last six years. His wife, Marie, 24, works as a mall attendant. He started with only a few items to sell. Now, he earns at least 2,000 PHP a day. He is thinking of hiring an assistant to attend to his customers.

Jessie found out about the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative through a neighbor early this year and asked staff to conduct an orientation meeting in his area. Jessie was amazed at the strategies and system of services CCT provides its members. Jessie is now on his third loan cycle with the cooperative. He has applied for a new loan of 10,000 PHP. He will use the funds to stock up on inventory for his store. Jessie looks forward to opening a second branch of his general store soon.

About CCT: The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response to poverty and social injustice. It is carried out through a fusion of social development initiatives and an evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. CCT serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
This is Marlyn F., a 42-year-old fish vendor from Tala, Caloocan City. Four of her six children are still in school. Her husband, Salvador, 46, is a driver. Marlyn has been selling fresh fish in the flea market downtown. She earns more than 10,000 PHP a month, mostly on weekends. Most of her clients are restaurant owners and busy workers.

Marlyn joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative only eight months ago, yet she is on her third loan cycle with the cooperative. She has applied for a new loan of 8,000 PHP as additional capital to keep her fish selling business going. She wishes to see all her children finish their college education in the future.

About CCT: The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response to poverty and social injustice. It is carried out through a fusion of social development initiatives and an evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. CCT serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Elmira's Group

texts.en:
Elmira earns her family's living by selling clothes. She has quite an unusual way of selling. She brings clothes from Turkey and, instead of selling them in a clothing store, she prefers to go around various companies offering to sell clothes. Not so long ago, Elmira used to sell bedding and underwear, but after looking at her friend's business, she decided to switch to clothes. This did increase her monthly income. Now it is around $165. Elmira needs a loan to purchase clothes for the fall season. She is planning to start saving money to buy a house. One of her dreams is to have her own clothing store.

Elmira is 44. Her family consists of four people. Having mothered two sons, she has raised them alone, being a widow. Her eldest son is 23. He is married and works in a micro credit company. His wife stays at home and takes care of the kitchen. This saves Elmira valuable time to do her job at the market. Her second son is temporarily unemployed. However, he often helps his mother carry and display the goods.

Elmira is the leader of this group and has the very radiant smile. Elmira's partners are Ainura, Venera and Elchibek. Ainura, 39, is divorced. She has one son, a school student. She works in a state agency with the government. She wants to obtain a loan to buy a washing machine – a purchase that she has been planning for a long time. In the future, Ainura plans to open her own news agency.

Venera, 36, is a widow. She has two sons; both are school students. She works in a financial institution. In addition, she sells clothes. She does not sell them herself; instead, she hires a salesman. Venera needs a loan to purchase clothes to expand her assortment of goods.

Elchibek, 36, is married. He has one son and two daughters. Together with his wife, they sell clothes at the market. They used to have a cow, and after selling it, they invested all the money in clothes. Now they make $360 a month. Elchibek needs a loan to buy more clothes.

About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en: Belinda B. is a 43-year-old woman who lives with her family in Malaria, Tala, Caloocan City. Her husband, Vicente, 45, is a mason. Their two children are both studying. Belinda has a small home-based general store where she sells food items like instant noodles and more. She is also into the direct selling of perfumes, cosmetics and women’s accessories. She earns a net income of P5,000 a month. Having been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative since 2006 is one of her treasured experiences. She currently needs a loan from the cooperative in the amount of P12,000 so that she can purchase stock for her store. She dreams of converting her small store into a grocery store someday. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her store

loans.name: Crisanta

texts.en: Crisanta E. is a 65-year-old entrepreneur from Bankers II, Tala, Caloocan City. Her husband, Filemon, 71, is a steel fabricator. Three of their five children are already working. Crisanta manages a steel fabrication workshop where her husband is the chief worker. Crisanta contracts with customers while Filemon rolls up his sleeves and does the hard work (as shown in the photo). Their shop fabricates steel gates, fences and more. Crisanta also manages a small general store beside their workshop. They also buy scrap metals and sell them to bigger buyers who in turn sell them to foundries. They earn more than P20,000 a month. Crisanta joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative just a few months ago. She is on her 2nd loan and has applied for a P8,000 loan to sustain her business. She hopes to have a bigger workshop someday so they can help their unemployed neighbors. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Kenjekyz's Group

texts.en: Kenjekyz is the leader in this group. She is forty five years old and has three children. Her husband is a carrier by trade. She has already married off one of her daughters who now lives separately. The other daughter goes to school. As well, she has a son, a college student. As any woman that has already reared her children until a definite age, when she no longer has to sit at home and look after them, Kenjekyz had long ago planned to start working some day. Until that very moment, she had been saving money to start her own business. And here it was, nine years ago this day came and she invested her savings in shoes and started trading. This determination of hers has already yielded quite impressive results. Due to her earnings, she and her husband have already bought a house, a car, and some convenience goods. Now, her monthly income constitutes around $470, which is considered to be a good income. Kenjekyz, currently needs a loan to invest in a new purchase of shoes and with the rest of the loan she wants to cover house-building expenses. Once she saves a sufficient amount of funds she is going to buy a container and help her son get married. These are Kenjekyz’s partners: Aigul, Gulnarida and Beishekul: Aigul, 35, is married and has four children. She trades in clothes, whereas her husband is a welder. Aigul makes $430 a month. She needs a loan to purchase more clothes to sell. Her future plans are to provide her children with education and to buy a car. Gulnarida, 25, is married and has one child. Nevertheless, she manages to be engaged in trade, as she sells women’s underwear. She borrowed money from her aunt to start her business. Gulnarida needs a loan to purchase more underwear and to add slippers to her assortment. Beishekul, 49, is married and is the mother of two children. Her husband does odd jobs at a construction site, and she sells nightgowns at the local market. Beishekul needs a loan to purchase more nightgowns. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a new batch of shoes and to cover house-building expenses

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn C. is a 41-year-old seamstress from Caloocan City. Her husband, Ernesto, 43, is an electrician. They have two daughters, both enrolled in college. Evelyn has been making school uniforms and other clothes in the comfort of her home for the last ten years. Most of her clients are parents asking her to make school uniforms for their children. She earns at least P8,000 a month. Demand is high during the opening of the school year and dwindles in the ensuing months. Evelyn became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006. She has just finished repaying her previous loan with the cooperative and has applied for a new loan of P16,000 to buy materials for making school uniforms (fabric, thread and other supplies). Evelyn works hard to support her husband in their desire to handle their daughters’ college education. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase materials for making school uniforms

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en: Mrs. M. Aisha, a 43-year-old woman, is married with four children. She has been selling clothes for over four years. She purchases used clothes from Owino market in Kampala and sells them in Mbarara. She is using this loan to purchase clothes to sell. She is a hardworking business woman whose dream is to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for sale

loans.name: Ma. Isabel

texts.en:
Ma. Isabel D., a 48-year-old woman from Malaria, Caloocan City, converted her house’s balcony to a general store six years ago. Her husband, Oscar, 59, is a bookkeeper. Two of their six children are still in school. She sells basic home necessities. Recently, she also started selling food items and fresh eggs. She enjoys her business a lot because she can help augment her family’s income without the need to leave the comfort of her home. Ma. Isabel now earns 13,000 PHP net income per month.

Ma. Isabel joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2007. She says the most valuable lesson she has learned with the cooperative is the need to save for the future. Ma. Isabel needs a loan of 12,000 PHP for the expansion of her general store. She wants to see her children finish their education.

About CCT: The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response to poverty and social injustice. It is carried out through a fusion of social development initiatives and an evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. CCT serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional business capital

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en: Mohamed is a 49-year-old married man with five children. He has a barber shop in Hebron in Palestine. He is special in his work because his salon is well positioned. His clients are his friends and neighbors. He is requesting a loan of $2000 USD from Ryada to purchase supplies for his barber shop, such us combs, creams, mirrors, and gels, to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for his barber shop

loans.name: Twaha

texts.en: Mr.  B. Twaha is a married man, blessed with five children. He owns a medical shop at Mbaguta Street and he stays in Lubuya. He is using the loan to purchase more medicine to improve on the stock so that he can be able to meet his customers’ demands. His future hopes are to improve and expand upon his business and more so provide better future for his children.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to improve on the stock so that he can be able to meet his customers’ demands.

loans.name: Anara's Group

texts.en:
Anara, 34, is a housewife. Her husband earns his family’s living by working as a driver, transporting various goods. Their three children go to school (her eldest son is graduating this year). Following their neighbors’ advice, they started keeping cattle. For now, Anara keeps two cows and sells the milk. Selling milk brings in around $50 a month, which constitutes a considerable contribution to the family budget. Without this income, it would take Anara’s husband much longer to buy a truck. Anara and her husband need a loan to buy spares for the truck in order to start providing conveyance services. In the near future, they plan to buy a house in the city of Tokmok.

Anara is the leader of this group. Here are Anara’s partners: Janyl, Amantur and Tumara. They live in a rural area and enjoy they lives. They represent hardworking middle income families, whose enjoyment of life springs from its very simplicity and their way of living.

Janyl, 48, is married. She is the mother of five children. Most of her children are grown-ups and live away from home. Her husband works as a builder. Janyl is a housewife. She keeps cows and sells nine liters of milk per day. Janyl needs a loan to buy one more cow. She wants to save money from selling milk to pay for one of her daughter’s college education.

Amantur, 24, is married. He drives a tractor and earns his living by offering transportation services. Amantur would like to obtain a loan to purchase some cattle. His dream is to build a big house in his village.

Tumara, 38, is married. She is raising four children, the eldest of whom is seven. Her husband works as an electrician, whereas she stays at home and sells milk. Her independent earnings have let her buy some furniture for the house. Tumara needs a loan to buy a stallion.

======================================
Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3 P's concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to further your support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy spares for the truck to start providing conveyance services

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn S. is a 42 year old general store owner who has also been in the food business for eight years. Her husband Nestor, also 42, works as a driver for a security agency. They have five children, one of which is currently attending school. They live among the poor communities in Malaria, Caloocan City.

Jocelyn has been cooking and serving food to her neighbors until she decided to put up her general store recently. She makes 15,000 Philippine pesos (about $311) a month of net income.

She has been with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative for three years now. Jocelyn is already on her 6th loan cycle. She needs a loan in the amount of 13,000 pesos to sustain her store and food business.

She dreams of having her own restaurant someday.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Yasin

texts.en: Mr. W. Yasin is a very hard working business man. He is twenty-five years old. He is married with three children. He is running cloth business of which he has been operating for over four years. He is using the loan to purchase clothes for sale. He is a hardworking business man whose future hopes are to own a self sufficient business and be a successful man.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for sale.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Miss Juliet A. A., 33, is a promising businesswoman. She is married with two children for whom she is willing to provide the best. She has a hardware shop in the Lyantonde trading center. She has been in the business for over five years. 

She is using the loan to purchase hardware items for her shop, hence improving upon the stock. She has very nice customer care and hopes for the best for her business. Her future dream is to increase the inventory and create employment opportunities for others.

loans.use: To purchase hardware items for her shop

loans.name: Medius

texts.en:
Miss Medius K. is the owner of a drug shop located at Bufunda 2, Bufunda ward in Ibanda town. She is 35 years old. She is a widow with two children, who are both in school. She has been operating a drug shop for over 10 years. 

She is using the loan for purchasing more drugs for her shop for more profits. She aspires to own a large-scale drug shop in order to sell a wider range and attract an awesome number of customers. She is a single mother but very hardworking.

loans.use: For purchasing more drugs in her shop

loans.name: Jeninah

texts.en: Mrs. K. Jeninah is a promising business lady, aged thirty years old and owns a saloon in kabwohe trading center. She is a married woman with three children. She has been in the business for over five years. She is using the loan to invest in her business by stocking hair chemicals, hair treatments, hair foods, rollers, etc for the excellent service to her customers. Also she owns a piggery farm and she will invest partly in the pig business. Her future hope is to increase on the returns from her saloon business and pig business

loans.use: To invest in her business by stocking hair chemicals, hair treatments, hair foods, rollers, etc for the excellent service to her customers.

loans.name: Shifubi Grace Namasule Group

texts.en: Grace N. is aged thirty-five years old, married with three children all going to school and looking after two dependents also schooling. Grace N. deals with a business of making bricks and more so she sells a retail shop for so far three years. She is requesting for the loan to pay wages to the people who helps her with the making of bricks and more so she is stocking more retail items in her shop. She is so creative and her future hope is to construct a commercial house for renting.

loans.use: To pay wages to the people who helps her with the making of bricks and more so she is stocking more retail items in her shop.

loans.name: Shifubi Khainza Florence Group

texts.en:
Florence K. , 42, is a hardworking businesswoman. She is married and blessed with five children, who are all in school. For eight years, she has operated a drug-shop business. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase medicine to add stock to her drug shop. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose future hopes are to improve upon her business, to purchase a plot of land and to construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase medicine to add stock to her drug-shop business

loans.name: Mercy Wabuyi Esther Group

texts.en: Esther W. is Mercy’s’ group representative, a 30-year-old married woman with six children, all students, and looking after two dependents also going to school. She has owned a grocery shop for over seven years and is requesting a loan to purchase grocery items such as tomatoes, onions, bananas, fish, cabbages, etc. for sale. Esther is a hardworking businesslady whose goals are to improve her business, educate her children and build a good house for her children.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items such as tomatoes, onions, bananas, fish, cabbages, etc. for sale.

loans.name: Pill

texts.en: Pill A. is a married Tanzanian businesswoman. She runs a business selling fresh milk to customers and also runs a tailoring mart at Buguruni ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the milk direct from the producers and sells it to customers  retail for domestic uses and for cafes. Pill runs the milk business in the  early morning to 10.30am, and in the afternoon to evening hours runs the  tailoring mart sewing different types of clothes.Through these two businesses she has managed to meet her daily family needs. Pill needs a loan of Tshs 800,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Mercy Masaba Sylivia Group

texts.en: Sylivia M. is a twenty- seven year old business lady who is married with five children in school. She is taking care of two dependents also going to school. She has had a spare parts business for four years. Sylivia is requesting a loan to purchase spare parts in large volume to increase her stock and her profit.  Her dream is to purchase a plot of land and to enlarge her business.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts in large volume .

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam A.  is a Tanzanian married small businesswoman. She runs a business selling second hand and new clothes at Buguruni Ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the business goods and the second hand goods   wholesale and sells retail to customers. She has run the business for five years and its income manages to meet her daily family needs. Mariam needs a loan of TZS 600,000 to capitalize her business.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Bishara

texts.en: Bishara A. is a married Tanzanian entrepreneur and small businesswoman. She runs a business selling mattresses and pillows at Vingunguti ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the  goods from the wholesale shops in the Kariakoo city shopping center and sells them retail to customers. The business income meets her family's daily needs. She is requesting a loan of TZS 800,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en: Zainabu M. is a married Tanzanian entrepreneur and businesswoman. She runs a food shop in  Vingunguti ward in Dar es Salaam selling varieties of food crop products to customers. Business goods are purchased direct from the producers and wholesale shops and are sold to retail customers at her shop. Zainbu has been in the business for four years and her business income is used to meet her daily family needs. Zainbu requests a loan of TZS 1,200,000 to expand her business.

loans.use: To capitalize the business by increasing the business stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ramadhan

texts.en: Ramadhani A., a married Tanzanian entrepreneur, runs a food shop at Yombo Vituka ward in Dar es Salaam. He sells a variety of products including wheat flour, maize flower, beans, sugar and cooking oil. He purchases the goods from the wholesale shops and then retails them to his customers at the shop. He has been running the business for six years and manages to meet his daily family and business requirements from his income. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 800,000 to buy more goods to sell.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Sadick

texts.en:
Sadick K. is a Tanzanian man who is a small business operator and an entrepreneur. He runs a business buying and selling salt in wholesale to customers of different regions but he lives at Dar es Salaam. He purchases his business goods direct from the producers in Kigoma Region and supplies to his customers in different regions in Tanzania. He has been in the business for the past three years.

The business needs enough capital in order to meet his customers needs. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 600,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more stock for his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase the business stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase stock

loans.name: John

texts.en: John S. is a Tanzanian an entrepreneur small business married man. He runs a business of Tailoring mart sewing different types of clothes including school uniforms at Yombo Vituka ward in Dar es Salaam. He makes both men and women wearing.  He purchases the business materials from the whole and retail shops in Dar es Salaam. He purchases two sewing machines from the business income and meets his daily family demand. He needs a loan of Tshs 800,000 to meet his business demand

loans.use: To buy more business materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more business stock

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria P. is a small-business Tanzanian married woman. She runs a clothes shop business at Kiwalani Ward in Dar es Salaam. She sells both secondhand and new clothes for both men and women and has been running the business for the past six years.

Gloria purchases her stock from the Karume secondhand-clothes city market center and Kariakoo city market shopping center. She needs a loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Revocutus

texts.en: Revocutus N. is a Tanzanian small businessman. He runs a food shop at Yombo Kiwalani ward in Dar es Salaam, selling a variety of food crop products. He purchases the goods directly from the producers and sometimes from the wholesale shops, and sells retail from his shop to customers. He manages to meet his family's daily demands from his business income. He has been in the business for the last five years. He needs a loan of Tshs 800,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business stock

loans.name: Said

texts.en:
Said A. is a Tanzanian an entrepreneur business married man. He runs a business of selling charcoal at Yombo Vituka Ward in Dar es Salaam. Charcoal is a main source of domestic power in most of the developing countries due to high cost and in efficiency  
Of other sources of power. He purchases the business goods direct from the producers in whole sales and selling in retail to his customer. He meets his family demand and capitalizing the business from the business income. He needs a loan of Tshs 800,000 to expand the business

loans.use: To buy more business stock

loans.name: Salehe

texts.en:
Salehe R. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur and a married man. He runs a café business at Vingunguti Ward in Dar es Salaam. He sells cooked and fried food including soft drinks to customers. He has been running the business for the past four years and his business income does a lot to meet the family’s daily needs.

Business materials are purchased from the wholesale and retail shops. Salehe needs a loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies for his business

loans.name: Said

texts.en:
Said B. runs a wholesale business selling food crops. He is a Tanzanian entrepreneur and a married man.

Said purchases his goods wholesale, direct from the producers, and transports the produce to Dar es Salaam market where he sells wholesale to customers. He sells maize, wheat, beans, onions and tomatoes in season. He has been in the business for four years.

The business needs high capital funds. Said needs a loan of Tshs 800,000 to push up the business by buying more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more produce to expand his business

loans.name: Eleswida

texts.en: Eleswida F. is a Tanzanian married small business-woman. She runs a food shop at Yombo Lumo Ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases and sells different types of food products including wheat flour, maize flour, beans, groundnuts, sugar, rice, and cooking oil. She purchases these goods from the wholesale and retail shops at Kariakoo city shopping center and other Dar es Salaam shops. The business income is used to meet her daily family demands and in capitalizing the business. She needs a loan of Tshs 800,000 to boost the business.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Ruth Roxana

texts.es:
La Sra. Ruth Roxana A. Q. tiene 27 años, esta casada con el Sr. Grover Mita Alba 5 años, tienen dos hijos que estan en la escuela. Viven en su casa propia en la zona de la Maica Norte a 10 minutos de la ciudad de Cochabamba, la zona se caracteriza por ser lechera y agricola.

La Sra. Ruth se dedica a la lecheria desde hace 13 años, empezó a trabajar desde muy pequeña con su madre que le enseño todo lo relacionado con el cuidado del ganado lechero. Ahora tiene su propio ganado lechero. Entregan toda su produccion a una empresa local que elabora toda clase de productos lacteos.

Requiere de dinero para la compra de Cascara de soya para almacenar en la epoca de sequia. Esto ayudará a que su ganado no este sin alimento durante esta epoca del año y su produccion no se vea afectada. Esto tendra un impacto positivo ya que sus ingresos podrian incrementar para mejorar sus condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Ruth Roxana A. Q. is 27 years old and has been married to Grover Mita Alba for 5 years. They have 2 children who currently attend school. They live in their own home in the zone Maica Norte, 10 minutes from the city of Cochabamba. This area is known for its dairy and agriculture business. Ruth has been working in the dairy business for 13 years. She began when she was very young, working with her mother who taught her everything about caring for dairy cows. Today she has her own dairy cow, and she sells all the milk to a local company that makes all kinds of dairy products. She needs the loan to purchase feed to store during the dry season. This ensures that her dairy cow does not have to go without food during the drought, and her production won't be affected. This protects her income and let's her grow her business, so that she can continue to improve her living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase feed for her dairy cow.   She will need to store the feed during the drought to protect her small business.

loans.name: Adelia Domitila

texts.es: La señora Adelia, pertenece al Grupo Mientras Tanto “Las Triunfadoras”, Distrito D. Bagua GranD., Provincia Utcubamba, Departamento D. Amazonas. Es casada, tiene 57 años, tiene 04 hijos ya  independientes y una hija que esta bajo su cargo.Adelia, es una mujer luchadora y con una capacidad innata para los negocios, desD. muy joven se inició con la venta D. refrescos, sus ganas D. sacar adelante a sus hijos le hicieron pensar en alternativas D. trabajo para mejorar la situación económica D. su casa y es cuando deciD. iniciarse en la venta D. refrescos D. cebada y soya, su negocio lo realiza D. manera ambulatoria ya que tiene clientes que  poco a poco ha ido ganando. En la actualidad su producto es consumido con gran aceptación por los transeúntes, que le compran D. manera diaria, por que ven que el producto que ella expenD. es D. buena calidad,  tiene buena presentación y buen sabor, sobretodo por que son atendidos con  cariño y amabilidad que es lo que ella transmite. Con este préstamo D. S/. 800.00, comprará una maquina D.  moler, jora, envases, Baldes, galones, azúcar por sacos, cebada, soya entre otros,  quiere tener todo lo que necesita para la preparación D. sus refrescos que es su fuente D. ingresos. Adelia, se siente con mucha energía, llena D. ánimos y ganas  D. seguir trabajando, y  aportando en su hogar, agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a tener oportunidades D. desarrollarse y seguir creciendo como personas.
texts.en:
Senora Adelia is a member of the group Las Triunfadoras, (The Triumphant), in the district of Bagua GranD. in Amazonas. She is 57 years old, married, and has 4 children. 3 of her children are independent, and one daughter Adelia still supports. Adelia is a hardworking woman with a good business sense. From the time she was very young she began to sell soft drinks. The income she earned helped support her children, and she continued to think about other ways she could improve the economic situation of her household. She decided to expand her business to offer barley and soy drinks, and began selling her beverages around the neighborhood until her customer base began to grow. Every day, many people purchase her drinks while passing by. She offers high quality, good tasting beverages and always treats her customers well. With this loan, she will purchase a blender, jars, glasses, sugar, barley and soy, among other ingredients. She would like to have everything necessary to prepare her drinks as they are her main source of income. Adelia, full of energy and motivated to continue working and supporting her home, is grateful to the organization of Manuela Ramos for giving women like herself opportunities to grow as individuals and improve their lives.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase ingredients needed to prepare her barley and soy drinks

loans.name: Anita

texts.es: La señora Anita, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Virgen de las mercedes II”,  Distrito de Bagua Grande, Provincia Utcubamba, Departamento de Amazonas. Es casada, tiene 42 años tiene 02 hijas mujeres que están en estudios superiores.Su espíritu alegre y su anhelo de ver profesionales a sus hijas, le motivaron a buscar alternativas de generar fuentes de ingresos y gracias a su cualidad de ser una mujer trabajadora y emprendedora le ayudaron a iniciarse en la venta de chupetes a través de jóvenes que le facilitan la labor, le esta yendo muy bien y poco a poco ha ido ganando clientes. En la actualidad ella abastece a  04 personas, que le compran en cantidad de manera constante, por que ven que el producto que ella ofrece tiene muy buena acogida y sobretodo son atendidos con amabilidad que es lo que a ella le caracteriza. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,200.00, comprará ingredientes para la preparación de su producto como azúcar en saco,  cajas de leche, 04 cajas de tecnoport para venta de chupetes, bolsas y vasos en cientos y frutas que a diario necesita para la preparación de los chupetes, quiere tener surtido su negocio, para así poder captar una mayor clientela. Anita, se siente con mucha fortaleza para continuar trabajando, y perseverando día a día y agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a tener oportunidades de desarrollarse en el medio donde se desenvuelven.

loans.use: Comprará ingredientes, para preparar su producto.

loans.name: Luz Flor

texts.es: La señora Luz, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Virgen de las mercedes II”, Distrito de Bagua Grande, Provincia Utcubamba, Departamento de Amazonas. Es Conviviente, tiene 38 años tiene 3 hijas, que aun están estudiando.  La necesidad de sacar adelante a sus hijas y de verlas superarse, la llevaron a decidirse por buscar una fuente de ingresos, ella inicia su negocio con un capital de S/. 300.00, gracias al consejo de una amiga que le comento sobre la existencia de una entidad que apoya las mujeres (M.M.R), comenzó vendiendo poco, compraba y vendía, hasta conocer mas gente, tener mas clientes, finalmente decide emprender con mas fuerza este negocio, ahora, cría en su casa donde tiene una mini_ granja de animales domésticos. Ella  con el apoyo de su esposo están haciendo florecer este negocio.  Con este préstamo de S/. 1,700.00, comprará mas animales como gallinas, patos y cerdos, para luego venderlos también comprará productos para su alimentación como, polvillo, maíz y vitaminas, ya que son animales que tienen acogida sobretodo en los restaurantes donde venden comida de la región, ella compra de diversos tamaños para variar sus precios y vender mas, así como también mantener a su clientela satisfecha.Se siente muy satisfecha con el trabajo que realiza, pese que es un trabajo duro y requiere de mucho esfuerzo, cree que vale el sacrificio para cumplir sus sueños y metas que tiene trazado en su vida. Así mismo agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por brindarle apoyo a ella y a  demás mujeres que quieren salir adelante.
texts.en:
Luz is a member of the communal bank "Vírgen de las Mercedes II" in the District of Bagua Grande, Utcubamba Province in the the Department of Amazonas. She lives with her partner, is 38 years old, and has three daughters who are still students. The need to support her daughters and to see them succeed has pushed Luz to decide and find a source of income. She started her business with 300 Soles following the advice of a friend who told Luz about an organization that supports women ("Movimiento Manuela Ramos", or MMR). Luz started buying and selling in small scale until she got to know more people and have more customers. Finally, she decided to take her business to the next level. Now she raises domestic animals in her house, where she has a small farm. With her partner's help, she is making the business flourish. With this loan of 1,700 Soles, Luz will buy more animals like hens, ducks, and pigs to resell them; she will also buy feeding supplies like powder feed, corn, and vitamins. The animals are in demand in restaurants, especially in those that sell regional foods. Luz buys animals of different sizes in order to vary their prices and sell more, and to keep her customers happy. Luz is very satisfied with what she does despite it being hard work and requiring lots of effort. She believes the sacrifice is worth it to achieve her dreams and the goals she has set for her life. She also thanks the "Movimiento Manuela Ramos" for supporting her and the other women who want to succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Violeta Rubiani, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying animals

loans.name: Eva Raquel

texts.es: La señora Eva Raquel, pertenece al Grupo Mientras Tanto “Las Triunfadoras”, Distrito de Bagua Grande, Provincia Utcubamba, Departamento de Amazonas. Es casada, tiene 34 años, tiene 02 hijos  a su cargo y en etapa de estudios.Eva Raquel, es una mujer luchadora y con una gran habilidad para desenvolverse en cualquier ambiente laboral, la situación difícil por la que atravesaba su hogar le motivaron a buscar alternativas de trabajo para mejorar su calidad de vida y gracias al apoyo de su esposo y su  facilidad de desempeñarse en este tipo de trabajo, le ayudo a iniciarse en la venta de repuestos, ella empezó con poco y con el pequeño capital que consiguió, instalo su tienda de repuestos, la cual cada día esta mas surtida y mas grande y poco a poco ha ido ganando clientes. En la actualidad tiene una gran cantidad de clientes, que le compran de manera constante en vista de que encuentran una buena atención de parte de ella. Con este préstamo de S/.  1000.00, comprará un exhibidor para poner las los repuestos, además, gatas hidráulicas, rayos de motokar, rodajes, aceites, grasa, tornillos, lleves, tuercas y cadenas de motos,  quiere tener surtido y bien presentable su negocio y dar una buena  atención a sus clientes para que ellos encuentren lo que necesiten y sientan que son bien atendidos. Eva, se siente con mucha energía y ganas  de seguir trabajando, y  aportando en su hogar, esta muy contenta, con la labor y el apoyo que le brinda el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a tener oportunidades de desarrollarse y seguir creciendo como personas.
texts.en:
Eva Raquel belongs to the "Las Triunfadoras" (The Triumphant) Group in the Bagua Grande district, Utcubamba province, Amazonas department. She is married and is 34 years old and has 2 children in her care who are in school. Eva Raquel is a hard-working woman with a great ability to cope with any working environment. A difficult situation which hit home motivated her to look for job alternatives so she could improve her quality of life. The support of her husband and her ability to perform this type of work helped her start selling spare parts. She began with little and with the small amount of capital that she acquired, she established her spare parts shop, which everyday is more stocked and bigger. Gradually she has earned customers. Currently, she has a great quantity of customers who buy on a regular basis because they receive good service from her. With this loan of S. 1,000, she will purchase a display case in which to show her spare parts, as well as hydraulic jacks, headlights, oil, grease, screws, nuts, motorcycle chains. She wants her business to be stocked and well presented and to give good customer service so that they find what they need and feel well taken care of. Eva wishes to continue working with a lot of energy and she is happy to be supporting her family with the work and support that the Manuela Ramos Movement provides helping women like her have opportunities to develop and continue to grow as people.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will purchase spare parts to increase her stock.

loans.name: Eliseo Ramon

texts.es: El señor Eliseo P. es un hombre trabajador desde joven ha tenido que ayudar  a sus padres ya que ha sido de familia humilde que ha tenido que trabajar desde pequeño, tiene 41 años de edad, reside en el barrio Memorial Sandino en la capital de Managua, su esposa le tiene 4 hijos dos mayores que trabajan junto con el y los otros dos no estudian debido a falta económica se le hizo imposible poder mandar a clase a sus hijos pues ha sido un año difícil. Su negocio es la venta de chatarra, cobre, aluminio. Anteriormente trabajaba como técnico automotriz el cual compro una camioneta para acarreo y ahora que vende chatarra, pues sus deseos es poder hacerle una casa digna a su familia ya que la que viven esta casi por caerse pero ha sido difícil poder construirla ya que lo que gana lo invierte en los alimentos y en lo necesario para el trabajo. Pero no pierde la ilusión de lograr tener una casa segura de concreto es por eso quiere invertir mas en la compra de chatarra, cobre, y aluminio para obtener mejores ganancia y comenzar a construir que es los anhelado. Da las gracias Afodenic por el financiamiento ya que lograra invertir en su negocio lo cual traerá beneficios a su familia.
texts.en:
Eliseo P. is a hard-working man who, since he was young, has had to help his parents since they are from a humble family that has had to work from a young age. He is 41 years old and lives in the Memorial Sandino neighborhood in the capital of Managua. His wife has four children: the two eldest work with him and the other two cannot go to school due to financial reasons. It has been impossible to send his children to class because it's been a difficult year. His business is selling scrap, copper and aluminu. Previously, he worked as an auto mechanic. He bought a truck for hauling and now he sells scrap. His wish is to be able to build a dignified home for his family since where they live now is at the point of falling apart. It has been difficult to build since what he earns he invests in food and the neceessities for his job. But he has not lost the dream of achieving a safe concrete house. It is for this reason that he wants to invest more in the purchase of scrap, copper and aluminum in order to obtain greater income and begin building what is desired. He is thankful to Afodenic for the loan since it allows him to invest in his business which in turn brings benefits to his family.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase scrap, aluminum and copper.

loans.name: Maria Esther

texts.es:
María tiene 20 años de edad, es madre soltera y vive junto a su pequeño hijo de 3 meses de edad en el distrito de Santa Rosa, ubicado a 25 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Ella se dedica a la venta de cosméticos desde hace un año, y hace dos meses ha empezado también a vender ropa para todo público, los cosméticos los compra vía catálogo y la ropa la adquiere en la ciudad de Lima; estos negocios son la única fuente de ingreso económico que percibe.

Trabaja en base a pedidos aunque también compra diversos productos en oferta para luego ofrecerlos a sus clientes, los ingresos que percibe de estas ventas los invierte en más productos para seguir vendiéndolos, ella está solicitando por primera vez a nuestra Institución un crédito de 1100 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de más productos y ropa para ampliar su negocio.

Su más grande anhelo es poder constuir una casa propia en la que pueda instalar un establecimiento en el que venda sus productos y de esta manera sacar adelante a su pequeño hijo.

María es considerada como una mujer valiente por su familia y sus vecinos, ya que frente a la adversidad ha sabido salir adelante y empezar a labrar su futuro.
texts.en:
María is a 20 year old single mother who lives with her 3 month old baby in the district of Santa Rosa, located 25 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. María has been selling cosmetics for one year, and two months ago she also started selling clothes for all ages. She purchases cosmetics from a catalogue and acquires clothes from the city of Lima; this business is the only source of income that she receives. María predominantly works from orders but also buys diverse products on sale which she later offers to her clients. She invests the income that she receives from these sales in more products to continue selling them. She is applying to Kiva for the first time for a loan of 1100 nuevos soles which she plans to invest in the purchase of more products and clothes to expand her business. Her greatest wish is to be able to build her own house where she can install an establishment in which she can sell her products and in this way keep her baby son going. María is considered to be a courageous woman by her family and her neighbours, as she has already confronted adversity and known how to get ahead, and has since begun to carve out a future for herself.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetics and clothes to sell

loans.name: Henry Peter

texts.es:
Henry tiene 28 años de edad, es soltero y vive en el sector Santa Lucía, distrito de José Leonardo Ortiz, ubicado a 5 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde el año 2004 tiene una mototaxi (vehículo motorizado utilizado para el transporte de carga y pasajeros) con la que solventa sus gastos personales, con la ayuda de nuestra Institución y con el fruto de su trabajo pudo comprar un terreno barato en una zona alejada de la ciudad donde ha empezado a construir una casa de material rústico.

El continuo uso de su vehículo ha hecho que este sufra serios desperfectos mecánicos en el motor por lo que se encuentra solicitando a nuestra Institución un crédito de 1200 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la reparación y mantenimiento de su unidad móvil.

Su más grande anhelo es poder comprarse otra mototaxi y con los ingresos que perciba en el futuro contruir su casa de material noble.

Henry ha demostrado responsabilidad y puntualidad trabajando con nosotros anteriormente por lo que es considerado como un cliente excelente.
texts.en:
Henry is 28 years old, single and lives in the Santa Lucía sector, a district of José Leonardo Ortiz, located 5 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. Since 2004 he has had a mototaxi (a motorised vehicle used to transport cargo and passengers) with which he covered his personal costs. With the help of a Kiva field partner institution and with the fruit of his work he was able to purchase a cheap plot of land in an area outside of the city where he has begun to build a house using basic materials. The continual use of his vehicle has lead to serious mechanical demage in the motor, which is why he is now applying to Kiva for a loan of 1200 nuevos soles which he plans to invest in the repair and maintenance of his motor vehicle. His greatest wish is to be able to purchase another mototaxi and with the subsequent earnings that he would receive in the future, build a house out of good quality materials. Henry has demonstrated responsibility and punctuality when previously working with Kiva´s field partner, for which he is considered to be an excellent client.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle repair and maintenance

loans.name: Leydi De Los Angeles

texts.es: La joven Leydi T. de 31 años de edad, se dedica ala venta de ropa y cosméticos que desde hace cinco años trabaja en las ventas, para aportar a los gastos de la familia ya que tiene dos hijos de 2 y 8 años de edad y desea  dar lo mejor a sus hijos y que logren un bien común, su esposo es mecánico desde horas temprana sale a su jornada. Reside en comarca Sabana Grande en la capital de Managua, Su negocio lo inicio con dinero que su esposo dio y préstamo Afodenic presto el cual invertio mas en el negocio y ha podido sastifacer sus necesidades, este es su cuarto ciclo el cual comprara ropa variada, y cosmético para seguir ofertando a sus clientes sus productos, lo cual espera aumentar las ventas y captar clientes nuevos. Da las gracias a  la institución por la oportunidad de poder mantener estable su negocio y que se que son muchas las familias Nicaragüenses que tienen el veneficio del financiamiento.

loans.use: Comprar ropa variada y cosmeticos

loans.name: Gladiz

texts.es: La señora Gladiz, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Sarita Colonia”, Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 42 años y es madre de 3 hijos, los 03 que aun dependen de ella.Gladiz, se dedica a la venta de gallinas, lleva 10 años dedicándose al negocio y se inicio  con S/. 250.00 y fue por iniciativa propia quien decidió emprender su propio negocio y empezó vendiendo en menores cantidades. En la actualidad continúa con el mismo negocio, ubicada en el Mercado Central “Pomarrosa”, donde exhibe sus animales.Con este préstamo de S/ 800.00, comprará gallinas bebes, para seguir criándolos y luego venderlos.Se siente con muchas fuerzas para seguir con su negocio. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  con el cumplimiento de sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Gladiz is a member of the communal bank “Sarita Colonia” in the Juanjui district of the province of Mariscal Cáceres, in San Martín. She lives with her partner and is the 42-year-old mother of three children, whom she supports. Mrs Gladiz sells chickens for a living and has been working in this field for ten years. She started her business with only 250.00 soles and only had a few chickens to sell. Today she still sells chickens in the central market called “Pomarrosa.” With this loan of 800 soles she plans to buy baby chicks to grow them and then sell them. She is very motivated to continue with this business and is grateful to the Manuela Ramos movement for helping her fulfill her goals and dreams

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase chickens

loans.name: Yelba Rosa

texts.es: La señora Yelba Rosa M. de 48 años de edad, casada, sus hijos son mayores de edad,  reside en el barrio la Luz en la capital de Managua, su negocio es la venta de nacatamales, sopas, también es dueña de una unidad de Taxi el cual se ayuda. Con este crédito comprara materiales de construcción para reparar el techo de su casa y poder estar en las condiciones adecuada en su  vivienda con su familia, cuando inicio su negocio lo hizo con dinero que su esposo dio, el trabaja de contador en una empresa privada, pues junto desean mejorar su casa y poder gozar de los beneficios de su trabajo. Desde horas tempranas se levanta para preparar la masa y verduras que lleva la preparación de los ricos nacatamales. Que son consumidos por muchos Nicaragüense, por su sabor y por su valor que es accesible. Da las gracias a la institución por dar  la oportunidad de poder invertir, como hacer las mejoras a su vivienda que es un  logro para cada ciudadano Nicaragüenses poder realizar los anhelos de un nivel de vida sastifecho para la familia. Ya que por condiciones diferentes muchos no lo gramos poder tener nuestra propia vivienda y es de mucha preocupación. Y  a través de estos financiamientos podemos salir adelante.
texts.en:
Mrs. Yelba Rosa M. is 48 years old, married, and has grown children. She lives in the La Luz neighborhood of Managua and sells naca-tamales and soups for a living. She is also the owner of a Taxi unit, which helps. She plans to buy building materials with this loan so she can fix her roof so her home is in good condition for family. Her husband originally gave her money to start her business. He is an accountant with a private company. They would both like to improve their home and be able to enjoy the benefits of work. She gets up early in the morning to make the dough and vegetables for her delicious tamales. She has many customers since they are so tasty and affordable. She is grateful to this institution for giving her the opportunity to invest and make some home improvements. These opportunities are beneficial for all Nicaraguan citizens so they can fulfill their desires for their families in a satisfactory way. For various reasons many people are unable to have their own home and this causes a lot of anxiety. It this through these loans that we can get ahead.
